metadata.case_name: Mst. Rafiquennessa v. Tulsa Devi & Ors. (C.A. No. 549/1962) and Wahedulla v. Abdul Hamid (C.A. No. 569/1963)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 549 of 1962 and Civil Appeal No. 569 of 1963

facts.text: Lal Bahadur Chetri executed a registered lease-deed in favour of Mst. Rafiquennessa on 14th February 1946 covering an open plot of land entitling lessee to build a house for residential purposes; lease due to expire on 12th February 1952 with agreement to deliver vacant possession.
Notice to quit served on lessee to vacate on 12th February 1952; lessee did not comply.
Appellant Mst. Rafiquennessa filed suit No. 149 of 1952 for eviction alleging contravention of lease terms by subletting the premises built by lessee; sub-lessees joined as defendants.
Lessee Chetri alone resisted the suit; sub-tenants did not join issue.
Trial Judge decreed appellant's claim for eviction.
Lessee Chetri filed appeal Civil Appeal No. 24/1953 in Court of Sub-Judge, Lower Assam District, Gauhati challenging decree.
Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (No. 12 of 1955) passed and published in Assam Gazette on 6th July 1955.
During pendency of appeal, tenant filed application to take additional ground under s.5 of the Act; lower appellate court allowed plea, framed additional issue, remanded to trial court.
On remand, trial court took evidence, conducted local inspection, found two houses built by tenant permanent in relation to locality but no evidence on construction date.
Lower appellate court allowed tenant's appeal, set aside trial decree, concluded houses constructed within five years after lease entitling tenant to s.5 benefit.
Appellant preferred second appeal No. 86/1958 in Assam High Court; High Court summarily dismissed following earlier decision on applicability of s.5 to pending proceedings.
Assam High Court issued certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Pending proceedings, tenant Chetri died; heirs Mst. Tulsa Devi and others brought on record as respondents.

In C.A. No. 569/1963, appellant Wahedulla filed suit against tenant respondent Abdul Hamid; facts similar, Act came into force during pendency of appeal before lower appellate court; s.5 application upheld tenant's possession, rejected eviction.
Assam High Court granted certificate in second appeal for C.A. No. 569/1963 to challenge earlier decision on s.5 applicability.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of section 5 of the Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 apply to proceedings pending between parties at appellate stage when Act came into force on 6th July 1955.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assam High Court erred in holding s.5 applies to pending proceedings; landlord acquired vested right to eject under lease terms before Act; statutes affecting vested rights should be prospective unless expressly retrospective or merely procedural.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: In re Athlumney Ex parte Wilson [1898] 2 Q.B.D. 547

petitioner_arguments.text: Legislature competent to enact retrospective laws affecting vested rights or contracts but must indicate clear unambiguous intention with express words.

respondent_arguments.text: S.5 applicable to pending proceedings as per Assam High Court earlier view; tenant entitled to protection having built permanent structures.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 5 of Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955

court_reasoning.text: S.2 provides notwithstanding anything in contract or law, Act applies to all non-agricultural tenancies created before or after commencement, indicating protection to prior leases affecting landlords' vested rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intended beneficent provisions to cover pre-Act leases.

court_reasoning.text: S.5(1)(a) protects tenants who built permanent structures within 5 years of contract date, either per terms or with landlord knowledge/acquiescence; scheme extends to pre-Act constructions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plain object protects tenants for structures built within 5 years of tenancy contract, even pre-Act.

court_reasoning.text: S.5(1)(a) prohibits ejectment except for non-payment of rent; prohibits eviction, not suits, so applies even at appellate stage where eviction sought; appeal is continuation of suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pending proceedings governed by s.5 if pending post-Act commencement.

court_reasoning.text: Retroactive operation inferred from express terms or implicit in words/context; here s.2 and s.5 clearly retrospective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assam High Court right; s.5 applies.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.5(1)(a) of Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 apply to pending proceedings including appeals pending after Act's commencement.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Athlumney Ex parte Wilson
precedents_cited.relevance: General rule on statutes not affecting pending actions unless express or procedural; exception noted.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955 (No. 12 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates landlord-tenant relations for non-agricultural urban lands; s.5 protects tenants building permanent structures within 5 years of tenancy from ejectment except non-payment; s.2 makes Act apply to pre and post tenancies.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed as s.5 applies to pending proceedings; tenants protected from ejectment having built permanent structures within 5 years of lease.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; respondents' possession upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the provisions of this Act shall apply to all non-agricultural tenancies whether created before or after the date on which this Act comes into force."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: S.2 indicates retrospective application to pre-Act tenancies.

key_quotes.text: "the tenant shall not be ejected by the landlord from the tenancy except on the ground of non-payment of rent"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core protection under s.5(1)(a) prohibiting eviction.

key_quotes.text: "an appeal pending before the lower appellate court is a continuation of the suit"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies application of s.5 to pending appeals.
